title: Introduction
description: Discover why we need programming languages like Python, and invent the idea of interpreters and compilers.

screens.end_comment: Yup, just 1s and 0s. Not exactly easy to read, huh?

screens.prompt: Can you guess what this does? `10110000 01100001`
screens.end_comment: It just loads a number into memory—but who could guess that from those numbers?

screens.prompt: If writing code like that is so hard… could we invent a better way to give commands?
screens.end_comment: Let's try using something easier, like real words or symbols!

screens.prompt: Here's a line in your new language: print("Hello!") — will the computer understand it?
screens.end_comment: Even though we understand that, the computer still only understands 1s and 0s. So… we need something to translate!

screens.prompt: What could help turn our code into 1s and 0s?
screens.end_comment: Let's build a program that turns our code into machine code!

dialogue.speaker: lumi
dialogue.text: What if our translator reads one line of code at a time, and runs it right away? Fast to test!

dialogue.speaker: nova
dialogue.text: Or we could have it read the entire program first, turn the whole thing into 1s and 0s, and then run it! That might be faster later.

screens.prompt: Which idea do you like better?

screens.content: Both are real strategies for running code.|Translating the whole program first is called compiling.|Translating one line at a time is called interpreting.

screens.prompt: Based on what we've seen, which one do you think Python uses?
screens.end_comment: Right! Python uses an interpreter, so it can run your code right away—great for learning and quick changes. Let's go write our first real line of Python!

summary: ✅ We invented a readable language—but we need to translate it.
✅ You discovered two ways to do that: compiling and interpreting.
